short_bio: Kevin Dundon is an award-winning chef and restaurateur based in Ireland.

ingredients: 2 lbs beef chuck, cut into 1-inch cubes
recipes.cooking_method:
1. In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat the oil over medium-high heat. Add the beef and cook until browned on all sides, about 8 minutes.
2. Remove the beef from the pot and set aside. Add the butter to the pot and melt. Add the onions and garlic and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
3. Add the Guinness beer to the pot and stir to scrape up any browned bits on the bottom. Add the beef broth, tomato paste, and thyme and stir to combine.
4. Return the beef to the pot and add the carrots and potatoes. Bring the stew to a simmer and cover. Cook for 1 1/2 to 2 hours, or until the beef is tender.
5. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

1. Preheat the oven to 425°F. Grease a baking sheet or line with parchment paper.
2. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt. Add the buttermilk and stir until a sticky dough forms.
3. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead briefly until it comes together into a ball.
4. Place the dough onto the prepared baking sheet and shape into a round loaf. Cut a deep X into the top of the dough with a sharp knife.
5. Bake for 30-40 minutes, or until the bread is golden brown and sounds hollow when tapped.
6. Cool the bread on a wire rack before slicing and serving.

1. Preheat the oven to 425°F. Grease a baking sheet or line with parchment paper.
2. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt. Add the buttermilk and stir until a sticky dough forms.
3. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead briefly until it comes together into a ball.
4. Place the dough onto the prepared baking sheet and shape into a round loaf. Cut a deep X into the top of the dough with a sharp knife.
5. Bake for 30-40 minutes, or until the bread is golden brown and sounds hollow when tapped.
6. Cool the bread on a wire rack before slicing and serving.

short_bio: Neven Maguire is an award-winning chef and owner of MacNean House & Restaurant in County Cavan, Ireland.

recipes.recipe_name: Slow-Cooked Beef with Red Wine Sauce
recipes.cooking_method:
1. Preheat oven to 325°F. Season the beef with salt and pepper.
2. In a large Dutch oven, heat the oil over medium-high heat. Add the beef and cook until browned on all sides, about 8 minutes. Remove the beef from the pot and set aside.
3. Add the onion, garlic, carrots, and celery to the pot and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
4. Add the wine to the pot and stir to scrape up any browned bits on the bottom. Add the beef broth, tomato paste, bay leaf, and thyme and stir to combine.
5. Return the beef to the pot and bring the mixture to a simmer. Cover and transfer to the oven. Cook for 2 1/2 to 3 hours, or until the beef is tender.
6. Remove the beef from the pot and let it rest for a few minutes before slicing. Serve with the red wine sauce.

ingredients: 1 lb mixed seafood (shrimp, scallops, clams, mussels)
2 leeks, white and light green parts only, chopped
recipes.cooking_method:
1. In a large pot or Dutch oven, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the onion and leeks and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
2. Add the potatoes and fish stock to the pot and bring to a simmer. Cook until the potatoes are tender, about 20 minutes.
3. Add the seafood to the pot and simmer until cooked through, about 5 minutes. Stir in the cream and parsley and season with salt and pepper to taste.
4. Serve hot with crusty bread.

1. In a large pot or Dutch oven, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the onion and leeks and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
2. Add the potatoes and fish stock to the pot and bring to a simmer. Cook until the potatoes are tender, about 20 minutes.
3. Add the seafood to the pot and simmer until cooked through, about 5 minutes. Stir in the cream and parsley and season with salt and pepper to taste.
4. Serve hot with crusty bread.

short_bio: Darina Allen is a renowned chef, author, and educator who founded the Ballymaloe Cookery School in County Cork, Ireland.

ingredients: 2 lbs lamb shoulder, cut into 1-inch cubes
recipes.cooking_method:
1. Preheat oven to 325°F. Toss the lamb cubes with the flour.
2. In a large Dutch oven, heat the oil over medium-high heat. Add the lamb and cook until browned on all sides, about 8 minutes. Remove the lamb from the pot and set aside.
3. Add the onion, garlic, carrots, and potatoes to the pot and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
4. Add the beef broth, tomato paste, thyme, salt, and pepper to the pot and stir to combine.
5. Return the lamb to the pot and bring the mixture to a simmer. Cover and transfer to the oven. Cook for 2 to 2 1/2 hours, or until the lamb is tender.
6. Serve hot with crusty bread.

1. Preheat oven to 425°F. Grease a baking sheet.
2. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
3. Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients and add the buttermilk. Mix until a dough forms.
4. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead briefly. Shape the dough into a round and place it on the prepared baking sheet.
5. Cut a deep cross into the top of the dough.
6. Bake for 30 to 40 minutes, or until the bread is golden brown and sounds hollow when tapped on the bottom.
7. Let the bread cool before slicing and serving.

2. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
3. Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients and add the buttermilk. Mix until a dough forms.
4. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead briefly. Shape the dough into a round and place it on the prepared baking sheet.
5. Cut a deep cross into the top of the dough.
6. Bake for 30 to 40 minutes, or until the bread is golden brown and sounds hollow when tapped on the bottom.
7. Let the bread cool before slicing and serving.

short_bio: Rachel Allen is an Irish chef, cookbook author, and television personality. She is best known for her approachable and family-friendly recipes.

recipes.cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 425°F. Mix together the flour, salt, and baking soda in a large bowl. Make a well in the center and add the buttermilk and egg. Stir until the dough comes together. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead lightly. Shape the dough into a round loaf and place it on a baking sheet. Cut a deep cross on top of the loaf. Bake for 30-40 minutes, or until the bread is golden brown and sounds hollow when tapped on the bottom.

ingredients: 2 lbs beef chuck, cut into cubes
recipes.cooking_method: Heat the oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Add the beef and brown on all sides. Remove the beef from the pot and set aside. Add the onions, carrots, celery, and garlic to the pot and cook until the vegetables are softened. Add the tomato paste and stir to combine. Add the beef broth, Guinness, thyme, and bay leaves. Season with salt and pepper. Return the beef to the pot and bring the stew to a simmer. Cover and cook for 2-3 hours, or until the beef is tender. Serve with crusty bread.

ingredients: 1/2 cup unsalted butter, at room temperature
recipes.cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Grease a 9-inch cake pan. In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. In a large bowl, beat the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs, one at a time, then beat in the vanilla. Gradually add the dry ingredients to the butter mixture, alternating with the buttermilk.

short_bio: Nernin Dundon is an Irish celebrity chef, restaurateur, and television personality. He is the owner and head chef of Dunbrody Country House Hotel in County Wexford, Ireland.

ingredients: 2 lbs boneless lamb shoulder, cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces
recipes.cooking_method: Heat the oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Add the lamb and brown on all sides. Remove the lamb from the pot and set aside. Add the onion and garlic to the pot and cook until the onion is translucent. Sprinkle the flour over the onions and stir to combine. Add the broth, water, thyme, bay leaves, potatoes, and carrots. Season with salt and pepper. Return the lamb to the pot and bring the stew to a simmer. Cover and cook for 1 1/2 to 2 hours, or until the lamb is tender and the vegetables are cooked through.

Pour the hot coffee into a mug. Add the brown sugar and stir until dissolved. Add the whiskey and stir to combine. Carefully pour the cream over the back of a spoon so it floats on top of the coffee. Serve immediately.

1. Preheat oven to 425°F. Grease a baking sheet.
2. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
3. Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients and add the buttermilk. Mix until a dough forms.
4. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead briefly. Shape the dough into a round and place it on the prepared baking sheet.
5. Cut a deep cross into the top of the dough.
6. Bake for 30 to 40 minutes, or until the bread is golden brown and sounds hollow when tapped on the bottom.
7. Let the bread cool before slicing and serving.

short_bio: Siobhan Boyle is an award-winning Irish chef known for her modern takes on traditional Irish cuisine. She is the head chef and owner of The Copper Pot, a popular restaurant in Dublin, Ireland.

recipes.cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 400°F. Place the sausages in a baking dish and bake for 20-25 minutes, or until cooked through. Meanwhile, boil the potatoes in salted water until tender. Drain the potatoes and return them to the pot. Add the milk and butter and mash until smooth. Season with salt and pepper to taste. In a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat. Add the onion and cook until softened. Sprinkle the flour over the onions and stir to combine. Add the beef broth, Worcestershire sauce, and mustard. Bring to a simmer and cook until the sauce has thickened. Serve the sausages with the mashed potatoes and onion gravy.

ingredients: Lemon slice and cherry, for garnish
recipes.cooking_method: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add the whiskey, lemon juice, simple syrup, and bitters. Shake until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with a lemon slice and cherry.
Preheat the oven to 400°F. In a small bowl, whisk together the olive oil, garlic, and rosemary. Season the lamb chops with salt and sugar
